sources.title: Man in the Attic
sources.description: With Jack the Ripper killing women in the Whitechapel district of London, people are on edge. Enter the mysterious Mr. Slade who arrives at the home of Helen and William Harley looking to rent rooms. Slade is a strange man. He is a respected pathologist and researcher at a major hospital but very much keeps to himself. He also happens to out of the house every time the Ripper strikes. Mrs. Harley becomes convinced that Slade is the Ripper but with tensions mounting across the city, the evidence is anything but clear.

sources.description:
Man in the Attic (1953) is an American suspense thriller directed by Hugo Fregonese, starring Jack Palance, Constance Smith, Byron Palmer, and Frances Bavier. Based on the famous 1913 novel The Lodger by Marie Belloc Lowndes, this film is one of the most atmospheric retellings of the Jack the Ripper legend ever produced in classic Hollywood. Colorized and restored by Colorized Public Domain, this edition brings renewed life to its eerie Victorian setting and psychological depth, making it captivating for modern audiences in the United States, Europe, and beyond.

Plot Summary:
Set in 1888 London during the terror of the Jack the Ripper murders, the story follows Mr. Slade (Jack Palance), a quiet, secretive pathologist who rents rooms in the home of William and Helen Harley. While he claims to be conducting medical experiments in the attic, his odd nocturnal habits, mysterious comings and goings, and detached demeanor soon draw suspicion. When a series of brutal murders spreads fear across the city, Mrs. Harley (Frances Bavier) becomes convinced their tenant is the killer. The tension deepens as Slade forms a strange bond with the Harleysâ€™ niece, Lily Bonner (Constance Smith), a music hall performer whose beauty and independence fascinate him. Inspector Paul Warwick (Byron Palmer) begins his investigation, closing in as the psychological and moral threads of the story unravel. The climax reveals a haunting blend of tragedy, fear, and misunderstood obsession, offering one of Jack Palanceâ€™s most memorable early performances.

Man in the Attic stands out for its chilling atmosphere and slow-burning tension. Released by 20th Century Fox, it was one of several postwar psychological thrillers that blurred the line between horror and mystery. Jack Palanceâ€™s portrayal of Slade offers an unsettling intensity, combining intelligence and menace with moments of empathy that keep audiences guessing until the final frame. The film also features Frances Bavier, later famous as Aunt Bee in The Andy Griffith Show, in a rare serious role. Shot in black and white, its visual style enhances the fog-shrouded streets and shadowed interiors of Victorian London, making it an excellent candidate for colorization.

sources.title: Man in the Attic (1953) JACK PALANCE
sources.description:
Stars: Jack Palance, Constance Smith, Byron Palmer
Director: Hugo Fregonese

In foggy London circa 1888, Jack the Ripper is loose leaving a trail of grisly, bloody murders! A beautiful showgirl is drawn to a reserved pathologist conducting late-night experiments in his attic. Could this mysterious man be the notorious, knife-wielding killer?

metadata.Plot: London, 1888: on the night of the third Jack the Ripper killing, soft-spoken Mr. Slade, a research pathologist, takes lodgings with the Harleys, including a gloomy attic room for "experiments." Mrs. Harley finds Slade odd and increasingly suspects the worst; her niece Lily (star of a decidedly Parisian stage revue) finds him interesting and increasingly attractive. Is Lily in danger, or are her aunt's suspicions merely a red herring?
